DOC.HEAD: Developments in Eastern Europe
Eds: UPDATES East Germany with thousands pouring through Brandenburg Gate, restores AP credit.
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at major developments in Eastern Europe today:

Army troops and citizens defending their day-old popular revolt battled units of the security forces that kept dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in power. Hundreds of people were killed in fighting in Bucharest and other cities after Ceausescu fled the capital Friday. His whereabouts remained unknown.

President Mikhail S. Gorbachev told Congress his government was ready to aid the forces in Romania that overthrew Nicolae Ceausescu only to find themselves fighting pro-Ceausescu security forces. But Gorbachev did not specify besides medicine what kind of aid Moscow was prepared to give the provisional government that struggled to gain control of Romania.

The top financial officials of the Solidarity-led government signed a letter of intent for the International Monetary Fund, pledging far-reaching and painful economic reforms in return for massive Western aid.

Thousands of East Berliners poured through new Berlin Wall border crossings at the Brandenburg Gate for a final, frantic day of Christmas shopping in the well-stocked stores of the West. Other Berliners headed for home after singing and dancing late into the night at the newly opened gate, which has been transformed from a symbol of Germany's divisions into one of East-West rapprochement.
